intro: Laphamia villosa, commonly known as the hairy lophanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely hairy foliage. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of the family. Laphamia villosa thrives in rocky, arid environments and is often found in crevices or on slopes. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and taxonomic studies.
